photos.caption:
‚ÄúMy grandmother had trouble walking. I used to hold her hand and walk with her. But my dad told me to ‚Äòlet her do as much as she can on her own, to give her the same sense of independence she used to have‚Äô. So, when she would walk to her bedroom, I‚Äôd pretend not to notice her. I‚Äôd always keep an eye on her though. 
Once she was having trouble getting into bed because her legs had weakened so much. I picked her up and sat her on the bed. She looked at me and started crying. I teared up too. She said ‚Äòyou‚Äôre a young boy, why are you doing this for me?‚Äù I told her ‚Äòyou‚Äôre my grandmother. I‚Äôm giving you the respect you deserve.'" (2/2)

‚ÄúMy mom was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis- the same sickness that my grandmother passed away with. I freaked out. My mom is my best friend. We have a very open relationship, and I tell her everything. If I have something on my mind or I need to rant, she‚Äôs the one I go to. Her sickness made me realize that I needed to be more responsible- I couldn‚Äôt be a care-free kid anymore. My mom has always been there for all of us. Now I need to be there for her and my family. I have two younger brothers. I don‚Äôt hold their hands and walk them through life, but I‚Äôm always there for them. If they do anything stupid, they tell me about it. I do what I can to help.‚Äù (1/2)

‚ÄúMy brother is a physician and my sister-in-law is a surgeon. They both work in Syria under extremely difficult circumstances. In besieged areas, health care workers aren‚Äôt allowed to deliver healthcare, or even food. If they‚Äôre caught aiding civilians, they‚Äôre accused of working for the other side. They suffer serious consequences just for doing their jobs. People are killed, maimed and imprisoned. Healthcare in Syria has become an instrument of war on both sides.

The health care workers do the best they can. It‚Äôs not a matter of political alliances, it‚Äôs a matter of helping fellow human beings. They‚Äôre working under extreme circumstances with very little resources. 70% of resources, hospitals, and clinics are destroyed beyond repair. Many of them deliver aid from underground caves that they use as makeshift hospitals. Nobody can hear their cries for help. They‚Äôre on their own.

The least we can do is say that there‚Äôs a community in Canada that cares. If they know we‚Äôre thinking of them, perhaps they won‚Äôt feel so alone.‚Äù

"Because of the bombings, many hospitals in different Syrian provinces have been destroyed. People often move to a private healthcare practice because of the long waitlists in the public sector. But private healthcare is very expensive, even for the wealthy. Both systems are doing as much as they can to get help, but many Syrians still can‚Äôt afford the required medication and services. A lot of local organizations have been trying to help but it‚Äôs a slow process. Everyone is trying, but there are still so many people that need help." "What are things students like us can do to help fight this healthcare issue in Syria?" "I think Canadians can aid Syrians financially to help supply medication and surgery equipment. But even more than that, the world needs to see that we‚Äôre much more than how we‚Äôre portrayed in the media. The beauty of Syria is constantly being overshadowed by images of war. But our country is so much more than that. It‚Äôs filled with beautiful places, culture, and with the beautiful spirits of Syrian people. This is the side of Syria that I want the world to see, explore, and to realize that we as a nation are full of hope and just want to lead a normal life‚Ä¶ Every night we hope to sleep peacefully, every morning we wake up hoping to get our country back - to live another day, walk down the roads without fear, eat good food and enjoy the evenings with our families. We just want to lead normal lives." (3/3)

‚ÄúWhen I was about to leave Syria, my friends invited me just to ‚Äòhangout‚Äô. I arrived late and saw that they had bought a cake and presents! I immediately thought ‚ÄúIs it someone‚Äôs birthday? Did I really forget that?‚Äù. I got really mad at them because I thought I wasn‚Äôt dressed well enough for the occasion and didn‚Äôt bring a present myself. But then I found out it was actually a surprise party for me! I really miss my friends and family.

When I first landed in Canada, all I saw was snow - no greenery anywhere! Everything was new for me in this country; the roads, the people, and the places. But my goal in life is to not be afraid anymore, and so far, living in this beautiful country is helping me achieve that. Canadians are very nice people. I see people here smile all the time and it makes me feel so warm and happy!‚Äù (2/3)

‚ÄúOne day I had an exam and there were four explosions. Going into Damascus they had blocked most of the roads, so the students on the bus had no choice but to get off and walk to the university. It wasn‚Äôt the safest walk and would take about an hour to get there. Luckily, we found a man with a car who was also going to the university to drop off his daughter, and so four other students and I all crammed into the back of his car. I remember he kept repeating, ‚ÄòEverything is going to be okay.‚Äô as he drove us to our university. We all made it there in one piece and I thought to myself - God stood beside us that day.

Most of my friends are still studying at the University of Damascus and I‚Äôm in touch with them every day. It‚Äôs so hard just to travel to the university. It‚Äôs also dangerous just trying to study there. Sometimes, they don‚Äôt have electricity and have to study with only the light from a candle. I can tell they‚Äôre tired of it all, but they still have hope. They‚Äôre just so motivated to graduate - it‚Äôs what‚Äôs keeping them going. Before I left for Canada, I had one last paper to hand in for class, and on my way there our bus was shot. When moving to a new country, you shouldn‚Äôt have to say ‚Äúgoodbye‚Äù to your home country like that. I‚Äôve only been in Canada for two months and they‚Äôve told me their situation has gotten worse. There have been more explosions. It‚Äôs war.‚Äù (1/3)

‚ÄúJoining clubs can help you discover more of yourself as a person. I thought that being in a club like the UofC Fashion Network was a great way to be involved in university. Back in high school, I was more focused on academics, so when I got here, I wanted to branch out and see what else I could push myself to do. I was really trying to find the things that I could grow into, and I did. 
I‚Äôm more of an ‚Äúideas‚Äù person, and I get to put them into action with our club. I also get to share and receive many other ideas that are bouncing around. More importantly, this club has helped me realize that there‚Äôs always another way to approach an idea, which pushes me to do better.‚Äù (3/3)

"It was actually by chance that I got involved with the UofC Fashion Network. I had a friend who was already a part of the club. At one point, they were putting up their posters around campus and I thought they might need help. At the time, they needed an executive that would handle marketing duties. I‚Äôm a marketing student, so the club and I just clicked. Being a member has been an eye-opening experience for me. Not only have I learned more about fashion, but the group has also helped me hone my skills as a marketing student." (2/3)

"Fashion is something that people usually take for granted because it‚Äôs just there; it‚Äôs easy to dismiss the clothes we wear every day. What people don‚Äôt always see is the industry itself, especially the ethical side of it. I believe that talking about the ethics behind fashion is a great way to get more people to understand it. I have high hopes for Calgary when it comes to taking part in this issue. With the direction that this topic and issue is going, there will be many more voices that can speak for the individuals that strive to make the industry a more inclusive and respectful one." (1/3)

"Death is a lot to that one person, and after that it‚Äôs done. The people who are left behind are the people you need to fight for. They carry the burden of grief. The person who has passed away doesn‚Äôt know what you‚Äôre experiencing. You are carrying the burden of their death and maybe you‚Äôre not mentally ill but mentally really really sick - I‚Äôve had the most outlandish thoughts. I was never religious before but you search for answers and you look outside of yourself for everything. 
The biggest mistake people make when they talk to someone who is grieving is that they say they understand. You think you understand, but you don‚Äôt understand. Everyone grieves so differently, even within my family. If someone else lost their brother, I wouldn‚Äôt say I understand what they‚Äôre going through. I can try my best to understand and relate but I wouldn‚Äôt understand. I‚Äôve lost two grandmothers, a dog, and you think those things are hard and sad at the time, and then you lose your 22 year old brother and it‚Äôs so different. It‚Äôs unlike anything I‚Äôve ever experienced. You don‚Äôt understand and I‚Äôm so glad you don‚Äôt understand. I hope you never have to understand. It‚Äôs unbelievably sad and hard and isolating and lonely.

At the same time, grief isn‚Äôt something you can compare. Sometimes, you meet someone and they change you in a way where their absence means so much. I don‚Äôt want anyone to feel like their grief is wrong. Someone might read his obituary and feel something: they might feel a stage of grief - they might feel denial things like this happen, or anger, or anything. Never downplay your own grief because you don‚Äôt know the person well. Get help if you need it. It‚Äôs okay to talk about it. Please feel free to ask me about Mark, I love hearing the sound of his name. If someone asked me March 12th next year, hey, it‚Äôs been one year since you lost Mark, I would be so sad but also so happy people remember him. 
Don‚Äôt tell me your brother is pissing you off. I don‚Äôt have a brother to piss me off anymore. If you have a sibling, if you have a parent, a friend, call them and tell them you love them. In the darkness of this all, there is the potential to laugh. My goal is to make

"Mark was an incredible man. He was so good at everything it was almost annoying. He played the stand up bass in folk bands and with his girlfriend Heather. He was an amazing athlete - he was a skier and he skied moguls like nobody I‚Äôve ever seen before. He hiked the West Coast Trial, he ran our dog every day, he was a great cyclist. And he was so smart. He wasn‚Äôt just a 4.0 student, he had an amazing mind and he was going to do great things and inspire so many people. He‚Äôd just gotten into a direct entry PhD program, he dreamed of being a professor. I was so excited to fly out to his first lecture as a professor and sit there in the front row, staring up at him. It makes me so sad that there‚Äôs a whole generation of kids that will never hear what he has to say. He didn‚Äôt halfass anything. He did it and did it well. He drew, he painted, he wrote letters to Heather so beautifully. Mark‚Äôs the type of guy there would be halls and university departments named after. He‚Äôs still with me in some sense, he‚Äôs with me in ways that aren‚Äôt tangible. He will continue to inspire me every day and I hope he inspires other people in this way. I hope when someone wins his scholarship, they look up who he is." (5/6)

‚ÄúThe biggest thing that changed in my life is the concept of delayed gratification. Mark was lucky because he did and saw a lot of things that he liked. He went to Europe twice on his own, once with the family. I know that if I died right now, I wouldn‚Äôt feel fulfilled and that‚Äôs so hard because I‚Äôm nowhere near done with my education. It‚Äôs hard for me to have goals and motivation. The one word I would use that fits everything that I‚Äôve done, the overall theme of my life, is motivation. I don‚Äôt trust that the world will wait for me, and now I feel like a shell of a person. I am passionate about many things and I feel like I‚Äôve lost the spark that ignites me. I‚Äôm not a determined student, advocate, or volunteer at this point, and losing that is so hard. I have to find the piece of myself that is missing. 
While I‚Äôve lost my drive, this reaffirms my passion and need to go into medicine. While I‚Äôm grieving and I feel like I have no drive, I see my mom and my dad hurting, panic attacks, crying. I get a lot of comfort from helping them. My dean asked me about whether I‚Äôd be ready to go into medicine. She said, if you saw a young man with injuries like the ones your brother had in Emergency, would you able to handle it? As much as I‚Äôve lost a lot of my spark, the way I see this is that it is a chance to win back another life, an opportunity to tell this unfair world that people can still fight to keep their loved ones here. When I think about my parents and my family, it inspires me to help other families and be a part of someone‚Äôs story, ensuring their family never has to feel this way.‚Äù (4/6)

"Mark and I grew up in Scenic Acres, so when we were kids we spent a lot of time by the ravine. We‚Äôd ride our bikes together, we would build lots of forts. We used to fill kiddie pools in our backyard with water from the garden hose. You know how our July evenings can get cold? One day, when Mark was probably about eight, Mark said he remembered reading somewhere that the ground would still retain warmth from the day‚Äôs sun. We decided to build our own ‚Äòhot tub‚Äô. We dug a gigantic hole in the lawn, and filled it with water from the hose. We then sat there in this mud pool, determined to enjoy something that we had spent so much time making. Dad was pissed when he saw us and the gigantic hole in his meticulous lawn. 
This is one of my favourite memories. My parents never put pressure on me, but I put more pressure on myself because now I‚Äôm the only Grosjean and I‚Äôm now living for two. I have this theory about memories - that if two people are part of a memory and both people forget it, it‚Äôs like the memory never happened. And all these childhood memories that Mark and I have, I‚Äôm relying on me and my parents to remember, and when they‚Äôre gone, it‚Äôs only me. If I forget something, it‚Äôll feel like it never happened." (3/6)

"We came back to Calgary and the funeral was the following week. That week of time was the biggest blur of my life. A lot of people came in and brought food, which was amazing because we had no will to do anything. I‚Äôm amazed by the kindness of best friends, the kindness of strangers, and everyone in between. People who I‚Äôve never talked to messaged me, and offered to help at this time. It‚Äôs sad that things like this bring out the best in people. I‚Äôm simultaneously restored in the faith of what people can do, but so angry at what this world can do. This world is unfair and people are all you can depend on. You don‚Äôt know what tomorrow can bring, but you know who you‚Äôre surrounding yourself with." (2/6)

"I woke up Monday morning and at 1 pm, I got the call that I was never going to see my brother again. When my mom picked up the phone, I heard her sobbing. My first thought was, oh maybe my dog got hit by a car, or my dad had a heart attack. It didn‚Äôt even cross my mind that my 22 year old brother would have died. He hit a tree in a severe ski accident and never woke up. The part that makes me most sad was that my mom was the first responder. She had to hold her dying son, and on the phone she was telling me how sorry she was that she couldn‚Äôt save him." (1/6)

Thanks to everyone who came out to our Humans of UCalgary x Scholars Academy Event last night! It was amazing seeing the connections being made and getting a chance to hear some of the amazing stories that were being shared. We're so glad to have had you join us for our Human Connection: Night Event to help make our vision a reality. We'd also like to thank our wonderful speakers again, Jill Drader and Rita Egizii for coming and sharing their stories with us. 
Be sure to look out for information on our next event which will be coming up in April! We look forward to seeing you all soon!

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre researching how children develop understanding of their language. One of the longest studies we‚Äôve undertaken here is called Babysibs. In this study, we work with younger siblings this disorder of children diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder to identify possible early markers of this disorder by carrying out a series of speech perception tasks and standardized tests over time. The studies takes a lot of time because we observe the children at various points between the ages of 6 and 36 months.‚Äù ‚ÄúFor the study I run with 15 month-olds, I always ask them if they wanna high five me. At one point, I had a streak of 19 high-fives in a row!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôve lived here all my life but I have family in Edmonton and BC. Since my parents have the biggest house of all my extended family, we often host the parties. Because most of my cousins are younger than me, I‚Äôm usually the de facto babysitter!‚Äù

"For me, dance is a framework where I can learn more about myself. My foundation is freestyle, whether in showcases or competing in battles. Freestyle allows me to take risks and explore boundaries within my movements. By immersing myself in the music that‚Äôs playing, while still remaining true to my style, I learn the most about who I am in that moment. Ultimately, my purpose as a dancer is for others to experience my emotions as their own, and to become an inspiration that drives them to be themselves through whatever medium they explore."

‚ÄúShe‚Äôs compassionate and humble. Anything she does is driven by passion and reason, and she‚Äôs literally the smartest person I know! I think she doesn‚Äôt give herself enough credit, but instead works even harder.‚Äù ‚ÄúI can always talk to him when I have problems. He‚Äôs caring and always puts a positive spin on things. Since I moved here from Ontario, he‚Äôs become a supportive pillar in my life. He's also very admirable with his mindset of always moving forward.‚Äù

"If you could win at anything, what would it be?" "In the context of sport, I want to be in a position to help somebody win a gold medal. Otherwise, I want to win a gold medal in living life. I would like, at the end, for someone to come and put a gold medal on my coffin and say, 'this life was the best, it was wonderful'." (3/3)

"Sometimes people think basic self care is wasting time. I like my brain a lot so, I have this rule for myself: try not to give the time that I should be spending on myself to other people. It's very easy to say 'yes' when people ask you to hang out, but it's important to be by yourself too. It makes me sad I don't do it more." (2/3)

"Hypothetically, I want to live until I'm four hundred years old, assuming that I can stay functional. I don't like the idea of being immortal because then things would lose meaning. But, the human lifespan is also pretty good. A normal lifespan is long enough if you make an effort to use it well. Looking back, I really should have bought a bike and rode it to Vietnam or some place like that, but I didn't because 'adulting'." (1/3)

"When I was growing up, there were always a lot of questions along the lines of 'What are you gonna do with your life?' But it was better not knowing the answer right away. It made more sense to explore and figure it out along the way. I‚Äôm now working in the health sector, but if I wasn‚Äôt working here I probably would have been in business - a career quiz led me to that idea.

I‚Äôve learned that you should be proactive with your career and who you are. Seek out choices, and utilize the resources available to you. Find out what works for you. It‚Äôs just like in health: it‚Äôs never as easy as telling someone to simply 'go get help.' Take honest, truthful steps to get to your goal. People will always have different paths to take. Reaching out for help might be the hardest at first, but it‚Äôs the easiest in retrospect. The more we ask, the clearer the way opens up."

‚ÄúHow would you define your friendship?‚Äù "It's having deep conversations with one another, but also making fun of each other without fear, since we've been very close to each other." "Friendship is also giving some Halls candy when you're coughing. We especially bonded over the time when we were taking Grade 12 English - also known as hell." "There‚Äôs also a lot of dark humor involved." "And K-Pop."

‚ÄúI‚Äôm in the symphonic band here mainly because of my band teacher. I returned my rented French horn at the end of grade twelve, and she told me ‚Äúyou‚Äôre too good to stop playing‚Äù, then gave me a horn that another teacher‚Äôs wife had donated to the school. I couldn‚Äôt pass it up.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy grandpa was an incredible man. He was a prominent doctor in central Vietnam and he managed a hospital in Hue. Even after the new regime took over the country in the 60‚Äôs, they let him keep his position. Thousands of people went to pay their respects at his funeral after he passed away last year. 
I‚Äôm in health sciences right now. It would be amazing if I could become anything like him.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy dad is an addict and it‚Äôs too late to do anything about it. He hasn‚Äôt been in my life in a really long time and I‚Äôve been feeling melancholy about that. It makes me a little upset that I can‚Äôt do anything to help him, as it would be somewhat last minute now. This is why I‚Äôm in the community rehabilitation program at the University of Calgary. I‚Äôd like to go into occupational therapy because I want to know what I could do for people like my dad, so that they can live long, happy lives and spend as much time as they can with their loved ones.‚Äù

"Straight out of high school, I moved from Georgia to California to play college football.  I was glad to leave Georgia. I don‚Äôt think people realize it, but where I‚Äôm from people can be aggressively racist and it's hard to feel safe anywhere. Junior college was tough too, though. There was a time where I was homeless and didn‚Äôt know where my next meal would come from.

Everyone comes from a different struggle. But at the end of the day, I have a son to feed and that‚Äôs what keeps me going. I want to provide him with a better life than I had. I hope to do this by getting drafted to the NFL. My former coach and mentor Dante Marsh always says ‚ÄúHow can they beat you if they can‚Äôt out work you?‚Äù This saying is a constant reminder to me to not only better myself on the field, but also in life."

‚ÄúTeyam is a glass half-full kind of person. An opaque glass, half-full of orange juice. She‚Äôs crazy. You‚Äôd expect to find water but instead you find orange juice.‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat?! What‚Äôs crazy about me?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs not crazy about you?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo you want to be a doctor?‚Äù ‚ÄúIn time. I want to really live my life first. There‚Äôs places I want to go see, experiences I want to have. This sounds dangerous but I want to hitchhike in Europe. I want to drink in an Irish pub. I want to study my ass off at a library that some of the greatest minds in history have also studied in. I want to see places and meet people. I feel like I‚Äôve been held back in the sense that I‚Äôve always known what I should do next. Nothing‚Äôs forcing you to do third year after second year but it‚Äôs always been obvious to me as the next sequential step. There‚Äôs not much room to live and experience. When you go to med school, you can‚Äôt hit the pause button for three months. And that scares me. I want to make the most out of my youth - am I still considered a youth? - before I‚Äôm tied down by other circumstances. These past few years have gone by so fast. Next thing I know I‚Äôll be 25, then 30, then 47. I need to go explore.‚Äù (3/3)

‚ÄúIn health sciences, it‚Äôs such a privilege to study with people who are genuinely passionate about everything they do. People volunteer dozens of hours a month because they want to make a difference. I have friends that advocate for Syrian healthcare workers and others that sit on councils to improve the hospital experience for kids. At the same time, it‚Äôs so difficult to not subconsciously stack yourself up against all of them. I was never one to compare myself to other people, but when you‚Äôre in an environment with people like this - it‚Äôs competitive and it‚Äôs not. It would be easy to be unhappy if they wanted to see you do badly, but they‚Äôre all so supportive. It‚Äôs not an active ‚ÄòI need to be better than them‚Äô, but it‚Äôs just a check of, they‚Äôre doing this, should I also be doing it too? How does my success measure up? It‚Äôs exhausting to spend so much mental energy thinking about what other people are doing. It‚Äôs not sustainable. It took me a long time, but I‚Äôm just going to focus on doing what I like doing to move forward. So I‚Äôm also proud of getting past the mental challenge of not comparing myself to others." (2/3)

‚ÄúWhat are you most proud of?‚Äù ‚ÄúI was part of the Alberta Children‚Äôs Hospital Foundation Youth Council, and we raised $20,000 for youth mental health. I guess I could say that. But honestly I think I‚Äôm most proud of getting through second year university. I burst an eye vessel before my o-chem midterm, and I burst another one before my o-chem final because I was studying too hard. Now I think I‚Äôve really screwed up my eye vessel because whenever I get stressed it feels like it‚Äôs going to pop. I thought there was no light at the end of the tunnel. I was sitting at the library looking through the dozens of reactions to memorize and I felt so hopeless. But I did it. It took two burst eye vessels, but I got through the course." (1/2)

"We were both drinking that night. I‚Äôd said no. I didn‚Äôt understand that what happened wasn‚Äôt okay. I didn‚Äôt tell anyone for a long time, and my relationship with my parents was strained because of it. I was angry and sad, and they didn‚Äôt know what was wrong - I didn‚Äôt know how to express it. I started talking to my cousin and she let me take my own time to heal. I finally realized that if I wanted a healthy relationship with my parents, I‚Äôd have to tell them everything. They were very supportive in the end. 
Once I came to terms with what happened to me, I started to advocate for consent and sexual health. That‚Äôs where my passion stemmed from, and it‚Äôs something that I want to carry on doing. I‚Äôm trying to make sure that other people feel comfortable coming forward. It‚Äôs important to support them and say, ‚ÄòI believe you‚Äô.‚Äù

"When I was fourteen, there was a protest against the demolition of an apartment complex that I delivered newspapers to. They were older buildings that typically housed the poor or elderly.  The city was going to demolish them to construct the Calgary Municipal Building. However, the city didn‚Äôt realize that they weren‚Äôt just run-down old apartment buildings, but they were a tight knit community.  I decided to try and capture that by taking portraits of the residents and their community involvement.  Together with other protestors we built a story on it and sent it to City Council. Unfortunately, that didn‚Äôt stop the inevitable demolition, but it caught the city‚Äôs attention and they were able to negotiate a community relocation of the residents. That was when I realized I wanted to pursue photography. 
Nearing the end of high school, I applied for a photography scholarship at the Banff Centre School of Fine Arts. I was granted the scholarship, but at a cost: due to conflicting semesters I had to drop out a couple months before my high school graduation. I did it without regret and it was there I met world renowned photographer, Peter Sanders. He offered me a job after I finished arts school, but I countered that if I could work right away I would drop out in a heartbeat. Next thing I knew, I was being flown around the country doing work for the Rolling Stones and Time Magazine, photographing bands and artist like the Ramones and Ted Nugent."

‚ÄúDowntown Calgary is a great place to explore. You don‚Äôt even need to use Google. Just walk around and you‚Äôll find a lot of cool places. There‚Äôs this bakery by Victoria Park station that I think is a great place for cute dates. It‚Äôs called the Manuel Latruwe Belgian Patisserie. 
I took my friends there and we walked all the way from City Hall to Victoria Park station because I didn‚Äôt know there was a Red Line!‚Äù

‚ÄúI‚Äôm currently in business, but I want to be a lawyer in the future. I read that finance is a good place to start.‚Äù
‚ÄúHow did you find that out?‚Äù
‚ÄúGoogle!‚Äù

"His name is Yousef and I just love him. He was only a year old when his dad passed away. His mom abandoned him because she wanted to experience life and get remarried while she was still young. He lives with his grandmother now, who‚Äôs old and has no income of her own. 
I don‚Äôt know why, but I feel responsible for him. He‚Äôs only four years old. We facetime every day and I‚Äôll be visiting him this month with lots of gifts. He‚Äôs my cousin, but I treat him like my child. I hope he grows up and gets an education. Without it, he might end up joining a gang- the same kind that shot and killed his dad."

"When you're a teenager, you only see the downs of living with your parents. But then, you realize that parents are more than just machines that raise a kid and move on. When my dad was brought to the hospital because of an abscess in his spine, I realized how much he's been there for me ever since I was born, and that now it was time I make sure that I'm there for him. There should be a balance between support from parents to their kids and from kids to their parents. It's what brought our family together."

‚ÄúWhen I was in first year, I wasn‚Äôt enjoying university. I felt lonely because lots of my friends from high school moved away, and I was too focused on my courses to make new friends. I knew something needed to change because I was seriously considering leaving university. That feeling of isolation didn‚Äôt go away until I got an email from the Haskayne Students‚Äô Association. They were looking to recruit new members, and this came at a really good time because I felt like I had ideas that would help other students who were also struggling adapting to university. 
The HSA called me back to join the House System Task Force. Joining the team was the first time I really tried to balance my academics with other activities. Working on the house system helped me get through those difficult classes because it gave me something to look forward to outside of my course work. I really tried to step up during the house system and was eventually elected HSA President. The HSA inspired me to continue with student leadership as SU Haskayne Rep and now as SU VP OP-FI. 
All of this taught me that you‚Äôre not always going to like everything that you do, but sometimes it‚Äôs not really about what you‚Äôre doing. It‚Äôs about how you get through it - and you can get through it - that defines you as a person.‚Äù

"I‚Äôve been solving Rubik's cubes since eighth grade, junior high. I remember how I found one just sitting in my room and I decided I should try it. I gave it a couple tries and it didn‚Äôt really go anywhere. Eventually, I watched some videos on how to solve them and taught it to myself in about 10 minutes. Years later it‚Äôs something I‚Äôm doing every day. I find it‚Äôs a good way to relieve stress and kill time. On my own, I‚Äôve beaten the world record for fastest time to solve a cube, but it has to be in competition to count, so I'm not in any record books yet. 
I usually bring a couple cubes with me most places I go, but I have more than 100 different kinds of cubes at home. The biggest one I have has 12 sides, 9 layers, 1212 stickers on it, and takes me about 3 hours to solve. The regular 3x3 cube has 43 quintillion combinations. If you put all the combinations on pieces of paper, you could line them up to pluto and back over 360 times. Basically what I have to do is find that one sheet of paper that has the combination. The 7x7 has more combinations than atoms in the universe, and if each of those atoms in our universe had their own universe of atoms, still only one of those atoms represents the right solution."

‚ÄúMy dad grew up in India as one of seven siblings. When he was a child, he was the only sibling given up to an orphanage for the disabled - even though he wasn‚Äôt disabled himself. This was because his family didn‚Äôt have the means to support him. When he was 22, he came to Canada. Eventually he gathered‚Äã ‚Äãenough‚Äã ‚Äãmoney,‚Äã ‚Äãreconnected‚Äã ‚Äãwith his‚Äã ‚Äãfamily,‚Äã ‚Äãand‚Äã ‚Äãsponsored‚Äã ‚Äãall‚Äã ‚Äãsix‚Äã ‚Äãof‚Äã ‚Äãhis‚Äã ‚Äãsiblings‚Äã ‚Äãand‚Äã ‚Äãhis‚Äã ‚Äãparents.‚Äã ‚ÄãMy‚Äã ‚Äãdad‚Äã ‚Äãis‚Äã ‚Äãnow‚Äã ‚Äãa‚Äã ‚Äãsuccessful‚Äã ‚Äãbusinessman‚Äã. He built a college right next to the orphanage where he grew up, and has‚Äã ‚Äãa‚Äã ‚Äãregistered‚Äã ‚Äãcharity‚Äã ‚Äãthat ‚Äãhelps‚Äã ‚Äãprovide‚Äã ‚Äãfree‚Äã ‚Äãcollege education‚Äã ‚Äãto‚Äã ‚Äãorphans‚Äã ‚Äãin‚Äã the community. 
My dad has shaped me into the person I am. My personal goal is to be a more loving person, not only to others, but also to myself. I want to treat everyone with open arms whether I know them or not. I want to be welcoming at all times and never stop smiling. It‚Äôs so important for me to not complain as much as I used to and to be grateful for everything I have. I‚Äôm fortunate to have visited almost a dozen different countries and experienced tons of different cultures. I‚Äôm planning to go to law school in the future, but to me, it‚Äôs not about making money, it‚Äôs about giving back to my community. If we can spend money to make someone else‚Äôs life better, then why not? We can work hard to make that money back, but who knows where it could lead them?‚Äù

"Forgetting who I am is one of my greatest fears in life, and after a rollover accident that should have cost me my life, that was very much my reality.  Suffering from partial memory loss, I came to a realization: moments are fleeting, and what‚Äôs really important are the memories and bonds you share with others. That is what sparked my wanderlust. No matter where in the world I travel to, people are my refuge and community is my home."

‚ÄúWhat makes you happy?‚Äù ‚ÄúBeing able to praise and worship God. He is my source of joy, love, and everything in between.

Growing up, my parents were of the faith. My youth was embedded in it, but I didn‚Äôt know as much back then. Joining a youth camp made me learn more about faith and God through praise, worship, and friendship. Really knowing God is the start of the journey.

Implementing the faith is something beautiful. There‚Äôs this thing called the ‚Äúbeautiful yes:‚Äù being able to say yes to God consistently. I used to be peer-pressured to do stuff, but I didn‚Äôt find authentic joy there. I was looking at the bigger picture. 
What we feel doesn‚Äôt always make sense, but I say yes to God‚Äôs call.‚Äù

‚ÄúBeing involved in nephrology has made me realize that I have a place in this world where I know I can make a difference. It has made me feel responsible for being a voice for my dad. 
Right now, my dad‚Äôs health isn‚Äôt improving. Both of his kidneys have failed. Dialysis is a life saving treatment, but it is not a cure. It‚Äôs also very painful. My dad gets cramps and uncontrollable twitches in his arms and legs. Dialysis will be the only treatment until he is matched with a donor.‚Äù (2/2)

‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt realize how serious my dad‚Äôs kidney disease was until over a year ago. It‚Äôs been a part of my life for the past twenty years - it‚Äôs something that‚Äôs become normal to me. I can remember the exact day I realized how fragile everything was. That morning, we dropped him off to get his catheter for peritoneal dialysis surgically inserted, and I was just heading to work in the building next door. 
I was a research assistant looking at the trends in the management of Chronic Kidney Disease. That particular day, I was looking at data on patients that started with peritoneal dialysis as their first mode of dialysis. I remember sitting there and trying to write my paper, and I realized that my dad would have been a part of my project - one of the numbers - had he started his dialysis a couple of years ago. 
At that moment, the numbers that I was looking at weren‚Äôt just numbers anymore. There was a story behind every single one of them. That one data point was someone‚Äôs entire life.‚Äù (1/2)

I‚Äôm in the process of learning from a few of my struggles. It's been a long road and I'm still making my way through it. This might sound corny, but you‚Äôve got to find the silver lining. If you can't find that, not only is the pain going to be worthless, but you‚Äôre not going to learn anything. Not everything is handed to you, not everything is easy. That's why they call life a struggle. 
Once you find meaning in it, you‚Äôll start to become a different person.

"My brother, Steven, introduced me to Bitcoin. We started investing back when it was only worth around two hundred US dollars, now it‚Äôs worth five thousand dollars! I really respect him and commend his incredible charisma and business skills."

‚ÄúAlzheimer‚Äôs disease is difficult to diagnose. So while a family can be fairly certain, there currently isn‚Äôt a way to provide a definite diagnosis and provide the family with time to prepare to take care of the patient. My grandpa is currently suspected to have Alzheimer‚Äôs. He lives with my family back in India. My aunts and uncles try hard to take care of him, but they aren‚Äôt always home and my grandma has her own health issues. This poses certain issues for him and the rest of the family when taking care of him; but we all really want to make sure he's as safe and comfortable as possible.

I‚Äôm currently a master‚Äôs student working in the BioMEMS and Bioinspired Microfluidic Laboratory. We‚Äôre working on developing a device that can detect Alzheimer‚Äôs earlier. This would help families find answers and adjust earlier to the financial and emotional demands of the disease. I‚Äôm really passionate on working on this project not only because it‚Äôs a personal one but because it‚Äôs applicable to so many families in the community that I am surrounded by. I would really love it if I am able to help people in some way or another facing these issues.‚Äù

"I came here from Serbia when I was one and a half years old. My hometown was being bombed by NATO soldiers, so my parents decided to leave and move to Canada. I lived in Calgary for seven years and then we went back to Serbia and Bulgaria. I have been back in Calgary for the last five years.

Back in Bulgaria, I had a really good friend in eighth grade. He was way older than me so I don‚Äôt really know how that happened. We used to take long walks in the city of Sofia and talk. I have no idea where he is now. Last I heard, he went to Spain to become a pilot.

I'm currently in first year Engineering. It's kinda alright, I guess. It‚Äôs hard to meet people in university since everyone‚Äôs so focused on what they‚Äôre doing. 
Sometimes it‚Äôs hard to feel like you belong."

‚ÄúIn Junior High School, one of my goals was to leave Calgary for post-secondary- to take advantage of the opportunity to explore.  It had stuck with me ever since and, before I knew it, my gap year was over and I had to make a decision.  I was set to go to the University of Victoria for Microbiology. I had everything prepared and the last thing for me to do would be to go.  In a turn of events, I got an acceptance email from the University of Calgary for a BSc in Psychology, which is something I‚Äôve been passionate about since Grade 10.  I‚Äôve always been fascinated with human behavior, how people think, and the motives behind our actions. 
After hearing the news of my acceptance, my parents wanted me to stay in Calgary. Family has always been very important to me. Last summer, I got the chance to visit Pakistan and my extended family for the first time in seven years. When it came down to it, I realized that my decision wasn‚Äôt only about myself, but also those who would be impacted. I decided to stay in Calgary to pursue my passion for psychology and to keep my loved ones close.‚Äù

"I‚Äôm the best procrastinator you‚Äôll ever meet. I‚Äôve been playing Geometry Dash and Solitaire on my tablet for almost two hours. I should probably be getting some work done though! I‚Äôm good at leaving things until last minute, but that‚Äôs okay because I can handle it. That‚Äôs just my workflow." ‚ÄúWhat do you have due?‚Äù "Just some assignments and a paper. Oh boy, I hope my profs don‚Äôt see this."

"I find studying human movement amazing because it's interactive and fun. My philosophy is to keep everyone moving - this is why I study Kinesiology. I like to carry around an orange ball that I throw to random people, which usually results in an intense game of catch! It also makes people smile, so I might also throw it around to anybody who looks bored or just needs a little bit of cheering up. 
I'm majoring in Leadership in Pedagogy & Coaching where I'm learning how to teach and share my passion for physical activity, especially with kids. I want to break down barriers that might exclude kids with disabilities from participating in physical activity.  I'm currently volunteering with the Adapted Physical Activity for Kids program, and today we finally met the kids that we were paired with! We played a lot and worked on identifying their goals. It was awesome."

Kevin Gardner, B. Commerce in Marketing (1985) ‚ÄúI was connected to CUS and I remembered that one of the guys owned a sod company. So near the end of the term, we had the brilliant idea to haul sod up to the eighth floor of the Earth Sciences building to build a mini golf course. We even built water lagoons with little goldfish. Because it was a fundraiser, we charged two bucks per person to play. But, it got a little out of hand. We spent all night cleaning it, and the university administration still wanted to charge us for a professional cleaning service even though we left it exactly how we found it. The bill was astronomical, but Dean Michael Maher thought it was so cool that we built this golf course that he said, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry, I‚Äôll cover it.‚Äù And that‚Äôs how the Golden Dino award came about. The Commerce folks had an award night called ‚ÄòYear End Dinner and Dance‚Äô. I was invited specifically to present the Golden Dino award, a plastic Flintstone dinosaur painted gold, to Dean Maher for generously paying the cleaning bill. I just had such a tremendous amount of fun while in Commerce! I left with so many fond memories of my time.‚Äù

"I really wanted to move to Canada. My mom's originally from Calgary, so I visited Calgary every year growing up. People are a lot less confrontational here; people aren‚Äôt as angry all the time. In the States, there‚Äôs some sort of superiority complex. I had a Social Studies class where all we talked about was America‚Äôs history. We never really learned about other countries in the world. 
When I was applying to schools in grade 12, I applied to the University of Calgary and Mount Royal University. I remember getting my acceptance letters in the mail. I burst into smiles for the rest of the week. 
At some level, I‚Äôve always wanted to move to Canada. I feel a lot happier as a person, I'd say I‚Äôve become a lot more outgoing here. I feel more connected."

Jeremy Ho, B. H.Sc (2009) "For my entire life, I thought I wanted to be a doctor. I joined the prestigious health sciences program thinking it would usher me into medical school. After second year, I went to Tanzania as part of the global health program and ended up returning there for the next six years. I was doing a lot of things that you guys are probably doing now - volunteering, research, trying to do things outside of being a health sciences student. In the process, I started working part time as a barista and became very interested in coffee.

I applied for medical school, I got an interview. I went to the interview, got out, and I thought I rocked it. I didn‚Äôt get in. I was crushed but it opened a lot of doors for me. I continued to pursue coffee on the side, and competed in the Canadian National Barista Championship. Because I didn‚Äôt go to med school that year, I was able to attend the World Competition and a lot of opportunities opened up. I applied for medicine a second time. My Dean told me the average applicant tries 2-3 times before they get in. I got another interview and I thought it might be my time. I came out and I thought I rocked it. 
As you can see, I‚Äôm still not a doctor. But business opportunities came up, and I ended up following my passion for coffee to start Monogram Coffee. I‚Äôm don‚Äôt work in health but I‚Äôve taken lessons from the program to where I am now.  I look at business in terms of doing projects - the project lives or dies via how you perform. Every business project is essentially the same: there aren‚Äôt infinite resources, you have a problem to solve, you have a product to get out. You see the same things in a research project - it has to operate, it has to produce something good. You know, I wish I paid more attention in organic chemistry. You never know what you will need in the future."

‚ÄúBesides death, I‚Äôm probably most afraid of languishing. Languishing as in living every day like it‚Äôs the same, being in an environment where I‚Äôm not having new experiences, not challenging myself. Life should feel vibrant, not like going through the same motions over and over. Routines are important in grounding what we do. We don‚Äôt need to learn a new way to brush our teeth each day. But the comfort zone isn‚Äôt a place where we grow.‚Äù ‚ÄúHow do you deal with this fear?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôve wanted to journal for about a year, but only started doing it daily three months ago. I‚Äôve already filled up a notebook. On the left half of each page, I write a day plan. On the right, I reflect on three parts of my day: what I did well, what I could do better, and how I want to approach the next day. This is my way of practicing mindfulness and making sure I‚Äôm conscious of how I act and behave. 
Journalling might only help me grow 2% each day, as opposed to 1% without. But growth builds upon itself ‚Äì it‚Äôs an exponential curve. And, in the long run, 1.02^n grows much more quickly than 1.01^n. That exponential growth leads to transformative improvement over time."

"I didn‚Äôt really know about anxiety until last year when I had my first panic attack. It started while I was hanging out with my friends. One moment
 you‚Äôre happy and the next everything feels like it‚Äôs caving in. 
The way I started dealing with things was by talking to my family and my friends. I think that if you are going through this kind of situation, it‚Äôs super important you talk to other people because it helps you get to the root of your issues and learn a different perspective. It‚Äôs eye opening, and really important to have people who are willing to listen to you.

The reason why I joined Outrun the Stigma is that I wanted to work towards creating a community that is willing to offer support. I think everyone exists on a spectrum, and everyone deals with issues in different ways. If we are willing to support one another and open up to hearing others‚Äô stories, we can learn to face adversity together."

"I was lost - very lost with what I wanted to do prior to university. I always wanted to be a doctor but people kept telling me to do certain things to become one. Their advice always confused me, and I didn‚Äôt know if I should listen to them. That‚Äôs why when I got to university, I had an existential crisis.

My TA told me to drop out of my degree during my first lab. I didn‚Äôt want to show that it affected me, so I made it seem like I was taking it
 as a joke, but I questioned whether it was true or not. I‚Äôd always question if I was good enough or confident enough to make it in that path.

I was fortunate to have my research published four months ago and that means a lot to me. It validated my choice in my Science degree, and it made me more confident. 
People are going to say some mean things but they‚Äôre not necessarily true. I want to help others achieve their goals and become more confident by talking about my own story."

Leighton Wilks, B. Arts. in Psychology (2000) ‚ÄúWhat made you choose University of Calgary?‚Äù ‚ÄúI‚Äôm an anomaly in that I did all my degrees at the University of Calgary -  Bachelor‚Äôs, MBA, and PhD. Now I‚Äôm here at Haskayne teaching. 
Doing my undergraduate degree here just made sense. I had a fantastic supervisor for my other two degrees - Dr. Julie Rowney. She was a super mentor to me and it was her that made me want to keep going on. She was the first woman faculty member hired here in Haskayne! 
Julie was always there to support me when I needed it and was also very hands-off when it was necessary. It was her guidance that really helped me. She gave that kind of advice that can only really come from someone who has had a lot of experience. The way she treated me really guides how I treat my own students now. 
I often think that I should just get a plaque that says ‚ÄúWWJD?‚Äù - What Would Julie Do?‚Äù (2/2)

Leighton Wilks, B. Arts. in Psychology (2000) ‚ÄúEmployers are no longer looking for a 4.0 student. They want people who are unafraid to do interesting, unconventional things. 
You gain such a wealth of knowledge by going overseas. You could go, come back, and then know what you want to do and get out of life. During my undergrad I left for a semester to travel to Europe, and when I returned I knew what I wanted to get out of school and it helped me realize where I wanted to go. I think too many people are focused on starting their career. They might not realize that this is the best time to get out there and embrace something new, and maybe discover what you want to be in the future. 
Now I work as an Instructor with the Haskayne School of Business and it has been amazing to give back to the program that has taught me so much. 
I came to love teaching cross-cultural studies from the great influence of a professor named Dr. Skarlicki. I can remember the exact day he spoke of it in a lecture, a light bulb flicked on in my head and I suddenly knew that was what I wanted to do. Now I teach a cross-cultural business course in Japan, and I took 22 students there in May! 
I never reached out to Dr. Skarlicki to let him know how much he influenced me. And it‚Äôs odd to think that we, as professors and instructors, might not realize the kind of influence we have on students. 
Sometimes I worry that I play the same role that Dr. Skarlicki did in the lives of my students, that I could impact somebody‚Äôs entire life and I would never know.‚Äù (1/2)

‚ÄúMy dream is to become an astronaut. Space exploration is fascinating to me. Right now, I‚Äôm doing research with the University of Calgary iGEM team, and we are developing a process to produce bioplastics on Mars from solid human waste feedstock using genetically engineered bacteria. 
Because I want to be an astronaut, people often ask why I chose to do chemical and biomedical engineering  rather than mechanical engineering. People think you have to go down a certain path to become an astronaut, but after talking to a few astronauts myself, I realized that‚Äôs not the case. Many astronauts have told me that doing what you love and doing it well is more important than attempting to follow someone else‚Äôs path to success.‚Äù

Nicole Fung, B. Comm in Accounting (2010) "I was born and raised in Calgary, so I wanted to try something new. I moved to Edmonton to study science at the University of Alberta because I thought I wanted to go into pharmacy, but I hated my first year so much that I ended up transferring. I decided to apply for business at U of C because I figured I could attempt climbing the corporate ladder. But I still wasn‚Äôt enjoying my career choice, dealing with numbers and spreadsheets every day. 
After graduation, I spent 6 months travelling, visiting Hong Kong, Australia, Japan, Korea and more. I just kind of decided: let‚Äôs do the things I want to do. Experiencing new food and travelling were always hobbies of mine, so I decided to create a food blog and Instagram to shared the different foods I enjoyed at various cities.

To my surprise, people really responded to it! It got to a point where updating my blogs and Instagram became a sustainable full-time job, and I couldn‚Äôt be happier."

Breanne Everett, M.D. (2009) ‚ÄúI never imagined that I‚Äôd be starting a company like Orpyx. In retrospect, I‚Äôve always been interested in innovation and entrepreneurship, since it‚Äôs the perfect storm of events, desires, and people involved. But I‚Äôve always been drawn to the sciences first and foremost. I never went into my medical residency thinking this would happen. 
Right now, our medical system is focused on reactive care instead of proactive, preventative medicine. I really want to see the shift to preventative technologies and medicine, because eventually our economy won‚Äôt be able to support reactive strategies. When I was completing my residency, I saw so many diabetics undergo unnecessary amputations. This could have been avoided if only they had the proper tools to regain sensation in their feet. Orpyx creates footwear that bridges this gap, by giving the patient real time feedback from sensors on their feet. 
I couldn‚Äôt have done this without the support from both the business and medicine faculties here. When I decided to step out of my medical residency, I had the complete backing of the university. My biggest fear was taking the risk of stepping aside and creating my own path to start a company. But this has been the most challenging and rewarding thing to do - creating my own trajectory. 
When life gets overwhelming, I usually ground myself with a tactic they taught us in med school. They always told us to take your pulse before before entering the trauma bay or an emergency situation. This grounds you. It reminds me that you don‚Äôt have control over everything and that you don‚Äôt know everything, but you can do the best with what you know.‚Äù

Shawna Trudel, B. Sc. in Kinesiology (1987) "I remember sitting in Science Theatres in 1981 when someone suddenly ran in and yelled, ‚ÄúWe got the Olympics!!‚Äù The entire lecture hall was filled with yelling and whooping. The following years, they began building Kinesiology B and the Olympic Oval. The renovations resulted in so much dust that the area was nicknamed ‚Äòthe dust bowl‚Äô. But I didn‚Äôt care, it was such an exciting time for Calgary.

In my last year of university, I worked with Athletics and found out they were hiring at the Olympic Oval. I originally wanted to work as a physical education teacher, but the opportunity to work on campus during the 1988 Olympics was irresistible. The experience was so exciting - I got to see behind the scenes. They hosted Entertainment Tonight and it was filled with celebrities. It eventually led to me working on campus for the rest of my career."

‚ÄúIf you could tell your first year self one thing, what would it be?‚Äù ‚ÄúI would tell myself to not buy any textbooks, unless assignments are associated with them. Even then, you could always borrow them from somewhere else. In my first year, I bought brand new textbooks for basically all my courses, and I didn‚Äôt open most of them more than once. Don‚Äôt cut down trees and don‚Äôt waste money unless you really need it for a course.

Also, make sure that you‚Äôre taking your courses with a professor that you think you'd be able to gain from. Sit in on lectures in the first week of classes and  know what to expect. Sometimes, some professors are really good for some students and really bad for others. You just have to know what kind of professor you need."

Dianne Tapp, PhD in Nursing (1997) "During my master‚Äôs degree, my research project was focused on one question, ‚ÄúHow can clinicians communicate better with patient families?‚Äù In health care, we sometimes only pay attention to the sick patient. But we often don‚Äôt realize that treatment has a long term impact to the entire family in terms of diet and lifestyle. 
Enabling families to communicate with one another about what distresses them helps everyone, including the patient." Subscribe to our weekly newsletter: http://bit.ly/SubscribetoHumansofUCalgary

Robert Thirsk, B. Sc. in Mechanical Engineering (1976)
‚ÄúWhat memory sticks out from your time at the University of Calgary?‚Äù
‚ÄúDefinitely my classmates. The U of C was a smaller school in the 1970s. My 1976 mechanical engineering class included only thirty students. We learned and worked together late into the evenings and on weekends on assignments and design projects. When I handed in a problem set, for example, my name was on it. In reality, I could‚Äôve listed several other names - we helped and depended on each other.
My engineering undergrad was an intense program that created a tight bond between my classmates. This bond has continued over the years such that we stay in touch. Every second Tuesday of each month, the Calgary-based classmates get together for breakfast. Last year was our 40th year reunion, and twenty-two classmates made the effort to attend. A piece of advice for today‚Äôs students - get to know your classmates. Help each other out. Likewise, get to know your professors. There‚Äôs some professor on campus who wants to learn about your career aspirations and guide you on your educational path. The full university experience should be defined by more than lectures, labs and the C-Train ride to and from campus.
If you had asked me when I was an undergrad if I would ever become an astronaut, I would‚Äôve replied no. I‚Äôve subsequently learned that it is okay to dream big, hairy audacious dreams. Admittedly, some career dreams such as astronaut require a lot of education, a lot of knowledge and skills. But be determined and keep moving toward it. You might be an undergrad now but you have tremendous potential. You could become an author, a neurosurgeon or Prime Minister. Don‚Äôt limit yourself by dreaming small.‚Äù (2/3)
Subscribe to our weekly newsletter: http://bit.ly/SubscribetoHumansofUCalgary

Robert Thirsk, B. Sc. in Mechanical Engineering (1976) ‚ÄúHow has going to space changed your life on Earth?‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crazy. Prior to my first spaceflight, I talked to many astronauts and read many books about what it would be like to live up there. But I couldn‚Äôt possibly understand how it felt to be in space until I was there myself. The view of the earth from space is particularly enlightening. 
On earth, we look up at the immense blue sky and may think that our atmospheric resources are boundless. From the orbital perspective, we quickly see that is not the case. If you imagine the earth as the size of a basketball, then the amount of atmosphere enveloping our planet is only a thin layer of tissue paper. From space, I saw the fragility and vulnerability of the earth: clear-cut forests resemble a patchwork quilt, ships emptying their bilge tanks into the ocean leave an oily streak in their wake. Prior to my first flight, I wondered if I would be able to see the Great Wall of China. Well, I couldn‚Äôt see the Wall from space because China was covered in smoggy haze. I had always been an environmentalist, but even more so after spaceflight. 
Physiologically, my body has largely returned to normal following my last flight. But my wife tells me that psychologically, I returned as a different person. Whereas community and national matters previously interested me, my wife says that the global community and big ideas now capture my attention. She‚Äôs right. I think it would benefit all decision-makers to spend two or three days in space to simply look out the window and reflect on humanity and the fragility of our planet. From orbit, we don‚Äôt notice individual countries; we notice only civilization. We gain the sense that all of humanity is one, that we are connected to each other and to nature, and that survival of our species should be governments‚Äô top priority.‚Äù (1/3)

Subscribe to our weekly newsletter: http://bit.ly/SubscribetoHumansofUCalgary

Robert Thirsk, B. Sc. in Mechanical Engineering (1976) ‚ÄúWhat memory sticks out from your time at the University of Calgary?‚Äù ‚ÄúDefinitely my classmates. The U of C was a smaller school in the 1970s. My 1976 mechanical engineering class included only thirty students. We learned and worked together late into the evenings and on weekends on assignments and design projects. When I handed in a problem set, for example, my name was on it. In reality, I could‚Äôve listed several other names - we helped and depended on each other. 
My engineering undergrad was an intense program that created a tight bond between my classmates. This bond has continued over the years such that we stay in touch. Every second Tuesday of each month, the Calgary-based classmates get together for breakfast. Last year was our 40th year reunion, and twenty-two classmates made the effort to attend. A piece of advice for today‚Äôs students - get to know your classmates. Help each other out. Likewise, get to know your professors. There‚Äôs some professor on campus who wants to learn about your career aspirations and guide you on your educational path. The full university experience should be defined by more than lectures, labs and the C-Train ride to and from campus. 
If you had asked me when I was an undergrad if I would ever become an astronaut, I would‚Äôve replied no. I‚Äôve subsequently learned that it is okay to dream big, hairy audacious dreams. Admittedly, some career dreams such as astronaut require a lot of education, a lot of knowledge and skills. But be determined and keep moving toward it. You might be an undergrad now but you have tremendous potential. You could become an author, a neurosurgeon or Prime Minister. Don‚Äôt limit yourself by dreaming small.‚Äù (2/3)

‚Äú4 years later, I had been to every small town in Nebraska, from Kimball, to Madison, to even Valentine. I hitchhiked from town to town with my amnesiac sister Dorothy in this fruitless search for my son. 
I was starting to forget what he looked like, what his voice sounded like, and what it was like to have him by my side. The only thing I could remember was the license plate '42WALB'. We got to Sidney with the help of an alcoholic named 'Crusher', and we went to the nearest McDonalds to get some food. In the background, I heard the manager yelling at an employee, 'Why aren‚Äôt you wearing your hair net? You keep getting your stupid silver hair in the burgers, you worthless child.' Silver hair? Could it be? I looked over at the counter, tears in my eyes, and I saw my son.

Sometimes I look back and think, if it wasn‚Äôt for that license plate, '42WALB' there would have been no way I could have found my son - Nemo, in Sidney, Nebraska.‚Äù (2/2)

"17 years ago, my wife left me after giving birth to our son. For 8 years I lived the life of a single father. I worked two jobs to keep a roof over our heads and to put food on the table, I skipped one meal a day just to make sure I could give my son three, and I was happy. 
But after years of barely scraping by, I lost him. I took him to the amusement park and he was taken. I remember him screaming, 'Let go of me you butt!' as I saw him being thrown into a white Pontiac Montana that started its engine and drove off into the distance. 
My son, my entire life, the only reason for my existence, was gone.

Why would someone take him? He was a very unique child, he had silver hair, Anemonesis, and other medical conditions. The only shred of evidence I had to go off of was the license plate of the van, the Nebraskan-registered licence plate '42WALB'. Everybody told me I was crazy. 'How would you find him?' they asked me. 'It would be like finding a clownfish in the entire ocean.' But if it was the last thing I did, I was going to find my son." (1/2)

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been volunteering with the Student Run Clinic at the University of Calgary since September. We were just a group of first year medical students, so the first few times we ran the clinic I felt like an outsider that dressed up as a fake doctor. Now, seven months later, it feels much more comfortable, but I‚Äôm by no means a real doctor yet.

The Student Run Clinic operates out of the ‚ÄòInn from the Cold‚Äô and helps under served populations. The most important part of my role is to understand the patient‚Äôs background. This is essential to treat them properly. We help a lot of diverse people from rougher backgrounds, people that experience more than any of us will ever have to go through.

I really believe in the work we do. It truly is a two-way street: our patients help us learn and prepare us to be physicians, while we help them access the health care they need.‚Äù

Elizabeth Cannon, B.Sc in Geomatics Engineering (1984) "Prior to starting my engineering studies, there were still some underlying questions from male students who may have thought, ‚ÄòWhy are you here? Why are you taking the place of a man?‚Äô These questions weren‚Äôt necessarily vocalized or pervasive, but they were there. When I entered engineering, there were only a few of us in number, but there was starting to be this realization that more women could do it, and should do it." If you'd like to read more of Elizabeth's post for 'Wayback Wednesday,' click on the following link: http://bit.ly/ElizabethCannon 
Subscribe to our weekly newsletter: http://bit.ly/SubscribetoHumansofUCalgary

To reserve a copy, please visit our FB page to sign up ASAP!!!
